title: Ticket #7654: ExprTree should be able to take an ExprTree as an argument
description:
David Gardner reports at HTCondor Week 2020 that classad.ExprTree can't take another ExprTree in its constructor, which makes it difficult to take input that might be a string containing an expression, or such a string that has already been wrapped up in an ExprTree. In particular, this should be True instead of erroring: 

>>> x = classad.ExprTree("foo == bar")
>>> str(x) == str(classad.ExprTree(x))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
Boost.Python.ArgumentError: Python argument types in
    None.__init__(ExprTree, ExprTree)
did not match C++ signature:
    __init__(_object* self, std::string expr)

(The string comparison is necessary because ExprTree equality produces another ExprTree.)
